summary: The ambassador of the Latin American republic of Miranda (Fernando Rey), M. Thevenot (Paul Frankeur), his wife Simone (Delphine Seyrig) and her sister Florence (Bulle Ogier) arrive for a dinner party at the house of Alice Sénéchal (Stéphane Audran) and her husband Henri (Jean-Pierre Cassel), only to learn that they were mistaken about the date. In director Luis Buñuel's surreal fantasy, the six bourgeois friends repeatedly gather for a dinner that never quite arrives.

reviews.content: Nonsense satire. Bored. Maybe I just couldn't get the French wit... Luis Buñuel has done a lot and this is one of them. I prefer his earlier works.
This is one of the most important and hilarious films of all time.
98% ? Why on earth were 2% deducted???

When a small group of bourgeois friends try to meet for an opulent dinner, they find themselves thwarted at every turn by circumstances seemingly beyond their control.  Initially, the meal is postponed due to a simple misunderstanding, but soon things escalate to unforeseen military maneuvers, police intervention, and a deceased restaurant manager, among other things.  Luis Bunuel's The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie is a scathing indictment of France's rich and powerful, a surreal satire that is unmistakably the work of Bunuel, the master of surrealism.  Cleverly written and constructed, it is as good as anything Bunuel ever directed.  It won't be for all tastes, granted, but for anyone who likes to be challenged by a film, The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie should satisfy their appetite.
Classic Surrealist filmmaking.

Characters dreaming of other characters having dreams never came off so well in a film where the, simplistic on the surface, plot revolves around six people attempting to share a meal together.

This aptly titled and totally bonkers satire was way more enjoyable than I expected, with Brunel keeping me pleasantly off beat, and with a big silly grin plastered on my face, for most of the film.

This was my first Brunel watch, despite being his 28th feature, and I was just as impressed with his writing as I was with his direction. The pacing was near perfect, with much of the plot action creating the impetus for the very next scene, allowing a natural flow to some of the most bewilderingly unnatural circumstances. The acting was spot on as well, and needed to be to pull off many of these increasingly absurd scenes. 8.5/10

NYT 1000 #278

What a monumental bore. I love international films and can talk Truffaut, Bergman, Kurosawa and Fellini with the best of them. But this is just unbearable. I guess you can say I am not a fan of Bunuel. I wasted two hours of my life with this.

Besides taking toll of middle class banality, the film is a great lesson for those who want to learn what humour actually is. This film will teach you that mere slandering, mudslinging and deride other doesn't evoke laughter but more feel and intellectual humour comes from exploring irony, tongue in cheek, banality, routine and horror of the repetition.

I think this is quite an interesting look at French 'society' - which they call the Bourgeois - which apparently has quite a lot less class than English 'society'. In England we call them boiled onions and it is fit only as a stock for making soup, in France they call it French Onion soup (although they probably just call it onion soup over there) and serve it as a meal, or worse they take quite disgusting food like frogs and snails and call it fine cuisine. It is this kind of attitude which makes everyone hate the French, Bourgeois or otherwise. France makes artists and England makes gentlemen (traditionally), not the other way around it would appear.

The characters are not really individuated and representative only of themselves but where they are symbolic of something else - archetypes. Here showing the various kind of people the writers presumably believe the Bourgeois to consist of - be it the half hedonists that just want to fuck, eat great food and live in a beautiful place, or the distinguished ambassador who believes himself to be a kindly socialist but actually is lecherous towards young ladies who want to kill him and murders people at dinner parties,  the rather unimportant man who has nothing whatsoever to offer except advice on how to make dry martinis and his drunken wife who is even less of a contributor. Although this is obviously all an incredibly sardonic slash at Bourgeois society for me personally there is nothing here that would distinguish the class as any worse than any other. No doubt the writers would have us believe that the working classes who, if we are to portray them in the same vein, f*ck mindlessly like animals, get blind drunk on trash to fight and swear at each other, stab each other to death in the gutters down some quiet street and see art and culture as a worse enemy than fascism as somehow more real and admirable. The problem here is not with one class and not another - it is with all classes. In fact eating good food with "herbs from the garden", knowing how to make a nice dry martini and enjoying a good f*ck is not something I would single out as an object of criticism.

I long ago realised politics causes many problems, will solve none and yet is still necessary. Therefore where before I had strong political leanings I now think about it no more than is necessary. But we are in the role of film critics, not political commentators and so should be looking at the Charm as a film. It did have some interesting bits. I like the 'play' dream, largely as I could understand it - showing how their dinner parties are all a show and nothing is really authentic and also the bishop becoming the gardener showing how even the church works for the rich. Some bits were a little more out of place like the lieutenant in the cafe, or the army showing up and the sergeant recounting his dream, it seemed strange but added interest and we could maybe drag some meaning out of it if we really worked to. The overall message of their dreams, I guess, was that the rich have all this paranoia, dissatisfaction and suffering  but that is not really something that is bespoke to the upper classes and quite honestly the lower classes need to change their ways just as much. This film had a complete lack of poor people - except where they invited in the chauffeur to drink as if to watch a monkey in a zoo.

I wonder if the arrests at the end hark back to the French revolution?

So although from a straightforward point of view the characters are paper thin and the plot lacks depth completely, this is another one of those films that is not art for art's sake but the director has some other message he wants to get across - here it is largely political and mostly about class distinction. And that message is also paper thin and full of holes from a philosophical point of view but we must allow people to express themselves in a way they see fit though we do not have to buy into their message, no matter how convincing and sardonic it is at first look. As a message or critique of life life it would be getting a very low score from me and some of those characters I would not even criticise too much, certainly not based on class or somehow worse than some of the working class archetypes, if one wants to f*ck and eat good food from the garden and make good cocktails so be it there are worse pastimes. The left wing message borne from hate for society people is tiresome. However, as a film it had some interest 6/10.
Mindbendingly genius! Another level. Surrealism at its peak!

1001 movies to see before you die.  I'd call this experimental and entertaining.  A bizarre story about people trying to have dinner, but it keeps getting interrupted by random things.  Some really unusual and memorable moments that were refreshing from recent movies I have seen.  It was on Amazon.

For many years, I simply couldn't watch this film as the world seemingly conspired against me.  It played for a week when it opened and had already vacated the theatre when I, excitedly, went to see what was to have been my first foreign language film.  A few years later, my college had a showing but alas I had finals exams the next day. Later, I rented a VHS tape, took it home, it wouldn't play. But years later another VHS tape did work. And of course you recognize my story as this film.  And perhaps for that reason this has remained my favorite non-English language film. Bunuel simply rocked my world with this one as life certainly does imitate art. I don't think I've ever laughed so hard during a movie as I was right there on screen among those dinner guests.  Perhaps Bunuel knew, on some non-linear level of existence, my story and filmed it, thus art imitated my life.  This is MY story, this is my song, my love letter to this film.

This movie kept appearing in my streaming recommendations and has off the charts rotten tomato meter but I have to say I regret trying it and I truly don't get it.  I couldn't get past the first 25 minutes of the movie with its mundane pace, dialog, and serious lack of engaging characters.   I am not against old movies, some movies stand the tests of time.  I sense an emperor's new clothes metaphor here where people can claim the pretentious movie critic title if they have seen this and rave about it.  Truly nothing to see here it should be dropped from streaming services, yes its that pointless and dull.

Umm...not sure what to make of this. What is it all supposed to mean. Exposing the entitlement and hypocrisy of the bourgeoisie, sure - but it just left me feeling it lacked something (not just a narrative thread).

I think my least favorite part of this film is that it isn't in my own language, I can imagine the humor landing more sharply if it wasn't delivered via subtitle (this is certainly not a film that you can just turn on in the background and expect to get anything close to the full experience). Regardless, it's still a funny film, a socially-focused surrealist comedy that revolves around the premise that, regardless of the bizarre circumstance and jagged, incomprehensible story, it is of paramount importance that these people not be able to eat a meal together. Before ZAZ would commercialize the format with mile-a-minute jokes in the ensuing decade, Buñuel used the distinctive style of humor to create a piece of social criticism that is all the funnier due to its bizarre structure. I can't help but feel that the language barrier has prevented my from enjoying the full experience that this film has to offer, though. (4/5)
It's amazing how Buñuel makes you follow his worst absurdity and most pure fantasies, and have you think it all makes sense.

Highly rewatchable, brimming with social commentary, and bold enough to make fun of the upper class without discomfort or unease,  "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie" is a masterpiece from the legendary Luis Buñuel by bending cinematic rules to shape a unique and unforgettable feeling of originality like no other.
A work of pure genius!
Bunuel defines surrealist cinema at it's most absolute with this picture. We are in the world of hunger.

I love surreal art, but apparently I am not a big fan of surreal films. Or at least not this one in particular. The first part is very boring, and when the craziness starts to kick in, it gets better, more interesting, and I started to finally get it. But too little too late I guess.

The movie follows a group of friends from upper middle class and their consistently interrupted attempts to have a meal together. They are experts on expensive food and drinks, know how to enjoy without haste, can afford to have bizarre whims, and their problems are mostly banal. They are characterized by nonchalance of those who know that they can, the flexibility provided by wealth, and by labor of others, as well as monstrous casualness of those who know they have an irreplaceable advantage over ordinary people.
Another surreal film by Luis Bunuel skewering upper-crust mores. Like many of his films, it gets under your skin and you don't have to understand it to appreciate it.
One of the best movies of cinematic history
Not funny or precise enough to be an effective satire. Although it is an interesting work of magical realism.

Entertaining watch, but far from my favorite Buñuel. Within the playground the filmmaker likes to explore, I find Belle de Jour and Exterminating Angel to be much more accomplished films. Still, it's always a pleasure observing an actor like Fernando Rey portray smugness in such a delightfully satiric fashion.

Talk about a disappointment!  I was excited to see this after rave reviews from others, but this was one gigantic snoozefest.  The characters were more or less interchangeable, the "surreal" dream sequences were unbelievably absent of artistic flair, and whatever humor there was just fell flat at every turn.  I'm not sure what others see in this film.
Absurd movie about high society people who never get to finish their meal and about dreams. Masterfully put together, great performances, just amazing. Highly recommended.

The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie is your typical Luis Bunuel film which relies too little on plot and makes no sense for the majority of time. Some segments worked, but most did not and the film was even annoying at times. It is your typical French comedy that isn't really funny and is rather overrated.
This is one of the funniest movies ever made.

Bunuel's transitions are some of the best that have ever existed. His attention to detail is impeccable. Interesting how in Bunuel's movies that have to do with people of upper class with money, there always seems to be the topic of terrorists entering into the story. Bunuel's imagination is endless. That scene with the kid seeing his dead mother and father was amazing. Jesus, all those dream sequences during the last 30 minutes of the movie were a complete mind fuck. 

Not really my kind of movie with the whole surrealist part of it all, but it was quite interesting to watch. I guess the rich and powerful never really get to eat, is Bunuel's message here. Bunuel, being someone who was against the rich and powerful, found a way to almost mock and ridicule the bourgeoisie to the point of satire. I can say without a doubt that there has never been a film made like this one. All the interruptions during the main story line and the ridiculous occurrences that happen throughout the movie would make anyone nowadays turn off the movie immediately. One must have patience and not question anything at all when watching this movie. You must remember that Bunuel is the master of Surrealism and his way of making movies is unlike anyone else. 

Nevertheless, this was an interesting movie with some even more interesting side stories from people who weren't part of the six main bourgeoisie.
A sophisticated, episodic farce beaming with slyness and discreet charm, as promised in the title.

This film is all about its unique execution.  It makes use of fantastical elements, dream sequences and satire to bring to life its major themes.  I wish I hadn't been so sleepy when I watched it since I'm sure I missed a lot of its nuanced details.
The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie boasts both an ingenious grasp of surrealist comedy as well as a playful, radical kind of creative independence.
Often hilarious, bizarre, irresistible lampoon of French nobility that is as clever as it is droll.

Amusing, surrealist film exposing the shallowness of the upper class. It's basically about a group of wealthy friends who attempt to eat dinner together, but are constantly interrupted. Throw in a few bizarre flashbacks and dream sequences, and this is one (intentionally) crazy film. It won the Oscar for 1972's Best Foreign Film. I'm not sure it's the classic many make it out to be, but I enjoyed it.
Surrealism at its best.
Bunuel's furious assault of the inhuman bourgeoisie is strange and immensely dry. 8/10.

Challenging Movie experience...
Winner of Oscar Award for Best Foreign Language Film, Luis Buñuel's "Le charme discret de la bourgeoisie " (The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie). 
Look at that title , Even that name flows off the tongue .Right?
Needless to say,It's tough to review a movie like this because no review could really do this film justice.And as in any Buñuel film, there's much much in the film than the plot.But let's give it a try.Well, I can introduce this movie as a Bunuel's sly, satirical and surrealistic reprimand on the capricious nature of humanity. 

What you are going to see is a group of people, all representing the upper middle class, spend their time attempting to have a decent meal. Also Bunuel interrupts the main story again and again with several secondary storylines. That's the simplest way to describe the film and this movie, which contains a simple plot as you are envisaging now , assuring you of one thing, that you will be dragged through a 'seriously what was it all about' situation at the end of the movie. And that's where the simplicity of the story is gonna deride you. In those secondary clips, *Spoiler* \ Several times throughout the movie the six main characters would be shown just walking along a paved road in the middle of nowhere. Here is my interpretation about that, because those clips should be understood since they hold a significant connotation, I suppose. Those scenes illustrate how weak and worthless they are without the lower class people surrounding them , they feel lost, they are not even able to interact with each other. Or Clips are used to make the transitions between other scenes or could be a dream. Who knows? /

No one is going to make a statement proving that only his interpretation is valid other than his name is Luis Buñuel. There might be many interesting and valid interpretations given by different viewers. Because Luis Buñuel is one of the world's most significant Surrealists in filmmaking and he also believed in leaving the viewers to their own individual interpretations. Surrealism is probably the best answer when an entire movie is based on interpretations like this ..

Once again, Hello ARTHOUSE + SURREALISM movie fans , Download or get your hands on a copy somehow!

Perhaps Buñuel's funniest film, and easily one of his very best. A sublime satire on upper class arrogance and negligence, The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie uses it's abstract plot-structure to stage some highly inventive scenes, including dream sequences that are surprising as they are wonderful. It's that rare type of film that tickles the brain as much as it challenges it.

The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie is one of those movies that need not to make any sense. It's about six people from the upper French class that attempt countless times to have dinner together but they never get to eat anything because they keep getting interrupted, even by their own dreams and fears. A very interesting premise, which apparently is BuÃ±uel's signature: mundane characters trapped in illogical surrealist situations. A great film, funny at times, even if I don't get all the symbolism just yet.

*SPOILERS*
Harkens back to old avant-garde films like "L'Age d'Or" and (most famously) "Un Chien Andalou" (i.e. the film where they take a woman's eye out with a razor...)

Pure dream-scape, this film can't be missed: once the "reveal" sets in more than halfway through the film, it's one "scene" after another. The hints that it's is all fantasy come early, with the reaction of the women (or total lack thereof) after the soldier's story being the most obvious tell...really, really magnificent. 

And it all started because someone got the dinner date wrong...and airplanes make it hard to converse. A+++

Once you see that the movie's poster looks just like that (the above image, which shows a pair of lips with legs wearing a hat), you can already tell that what you'll see is just going to be so odd and it's just going to mess with your mind.

This came in the outstanding 10-DVD boxed set 'Rialto Pictures: 10 Years', one of the finest things I've bought from The Criterion Collection (and a great deal too, one I'd heartily endorse).

I had to wait an entire day, after watching the dreadful 'Disaster Movie', to get the acrid taste out of my mouth to watch this one, by my fourth favourite director ever ('Viridiana' is still probably my favourite of his, though). Luckily it had three of my favourite French actors from the period, in Bulle Ogier (just check out 'Maitresse' if you don't understand why), Delphine Seyrig and Fernando Rey (for the two 'French Connection' films alone)--even though for a director of Bunuel's strength, any actors could have sufficed. It's the ideas that stand out most triumphantly.

It's most known for being Bunuel's Oscar-winner for Best Foreign Language Film, but its OTHER nomination is what's almost neglected when people talk about him. Yes, they talk about Bunuel the director, or (from David Thomson) Bunuel the photographer, but people never realize his two nominations for the Calanda, Spain-native were never for director, but for writing (with another nod for his swan song, 'The Obscure Object of Desire').

This is a bit of a puzzle of a movie. I have to admit it, I didn't really get it and found it quite confusing. It's not a bad watch, it's surreal and contains several dream sequences which you have to try and separate from the reality which is also questionable. It's a challenge but worth a go.

The scathing critique on capitalism and corruption that The Wolf Of Wall Street should have been. It's brilliant in the audience manipulation that Brunel delivers as he shows the first-world its cynical hypocrisy in all its comical glory and wonder. While some jabs at the Church and dreaming falls flat, the director's surrealism makes up for it as he treats us to a feast that polite society can never sit at no matter how hard they try to. Plus, Brunel makes you laugh-out loud while thinking at society's errors.

Strange and a classic of the art house films of the time. Truly unique in its strangeness and surreal aspects, it begins in a fairly normal fashion only to slowly spiral into a series of increasingly outlandish situations one might not think would be down the line considering the beginning. At the heart of this film is satire as it attacks upper class and sentiments and norms. The humor manages not only to make the satire more rich, but to make this one fun to watch.

Empty and dated. 41 years have done nothing for this over-blown gadget piece. After about thirty minutes of this nonsense you realize any unfinished business (including lunch and dinner) will segue out of one of the characters dreams and into the next diversion. Cogito ergo sum - the novelty wears off quickly.

Dark, biting, surreal, weird, disturbing...you can spot a Bunuel movie a mile away.  I'll have to watch it again to understand it a little better but this was a great film. The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie clearly shows then aging director Luis Bunuel still in his prime, still experimenting with what is real and what is imagined.  One surreally disturbing scene shows a flashback to a young man's childhood, where his pale desist mother appears to her son to show him his real father, also desist, standing in the room with them with blood all over his face then instructs the young boy to poison the man claiming to be his father.  That is the kind of thing you watch a Bunuel movie for.  With all that and the sexual and drug content, how in the hell is a PG movie?

ABSOLUTELY BRILLIANT! Bunuel is the master of surrealist cinema. A romp through of the petty anxieties of society's masters, with pointed comic metaphors about their institutional lackeys. Unforgettable film.

This is satire with the capital letter. I love that Bunuel's style, his views and how he brings them up to the viewer. He's a genial director. Just watch how he easily he changes focus from one object to another, from one theme to another and that is in one complex scene. And of course his impregnations of surrealism.
This is what I call bizarre in the most pure and funniest form, I really enjoy it!
What an oddly enjoyable little film...and it quite unexpectedly reminded me of Inception.

This is a movie I'm going to have to see again. Not because I have questions, but I want to experience whatever that was again. I did enjoy its surreal moments and its subtle satire, it's pretty funny and overall thought it was a pretty good movie. However, there were parts that I thought were dull, and I was slightly confused by the ending. This is the first film I've seen by Bunuel, but overall, I enjoyed it.

Yes another Bunuel film. I was more interested in this film's story than Andalou because I could understand it more, even though it still seemed like a Bunuel film with it's randomness and disconnections that were a bit difficult to understand and keep track of. Nonetheless, this is still a brilliant film.
The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie, I give you a 90%.
Hilarious and revolting, full of terrible people you cant bring yourself to hate. at its best when it gets surreal and seemlessy lands back into a poignantly awkward reality.
I'm not even sure what to make of this film. It will definitely require a second viewing.

Honestly I'm still not sure what the heck that was. It was all so easy to take in while I was watching it - perhaps a result of it being somewhat dated - but when I think back to it, I keep realizing how surreal it all was. The clever use of absurdity somehow manages to at times be profound, at others just silly, sometimes confusing and other times perfectly normal. In many cases, it's all of these at the same time. Very strange, I feel like my view of cinema has been challenged... yet this was only a movie about a bourgeois sextet attempting to have dinner.
Bunuel is a true surrealist in which dreams are in dreams and confusion is all around. I really dug this and would like to see it again.

Written and directed by Luis Buñuel, who had returned to Europe in the 1960's after an 'exile' in America and Mexico. He'd moved to France and with help from screenwriter Jean-Claude Carrière and producer Serge Silberman created films like Diary of a Chambermaid (1964) and Belle de Jour (1967) which were hits internationally. Then he did this, which was a savage return to the surrealism of Un Chien Andalou (1927). The film has no plot so to speak of, but it's connected by a series of dreams, all revolving around a group of people Monsieur Thévenot (Paul Frankeur) and his wife Simone (Delphine Seyrig) and her sister Florence (Bulle Ogier). There's also Henri Sénéchal (Jean-Pierre Cassel) and his wife Alice (Stéphane Audran), and they're joined by foreign ambassador Rafael Acosta (Fernando Rey). It follows their attempts to have several dinner parties together and outside forces preventing them from doing so, like a nearby army base firing at the house, and everyone getting arrested for no reason. It's very surreal, and you don't get films that leave everything unexplained like this anymore. But it's well filmed, and amongst it's fans were Alfred Hitchcock, Billy Wilder, John Ford and Robert Wise. The film won the Oscar for Best Foreign Language Film too.
It's hard to get the cool meal you dream of these days
It's amazing how this film it's still current some 40 years later after its first debut.

A surrealistic masterpiece. Luis Buñuel, the greatest filmmaker involved with André Breton's French Surrealistic Movement, depicts the bourgeoisie in all of its hypocritical greatness, or un-greatness. Stemming from 'the language of the absurd' (where language itself is irrational) and automatic speech-- philosophic meditations practiced by the surrealists-- Buñuel creates a dream-world of dimensions into the unknown, and dreams within dreams. Adhering to the values of nonconformism, The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie comically explores the contradictories of mundane upper-class society, exposing society that reduces all human aspiration to market values, religious impostures, universal boredom and misery. Not Luis Buñuel's magnum opus ("L'Age d'Or" being his best work), but still a significant contribution (among many of his other great films) to one of the most controversial revolutionary movements of the twentieth century.
Comic masterpiece. BuÃ±uel makes fun of the French Bourgeoisie people in the wildest and funniest way imaginable. His most accessible surreal film. Don't miss this one.
Wildly weird and funny. This great flick pokes fun at the upper class and all of their distinctly surreal problems.

If you have no sense of humor going into this, you wont get it at all.  This film has a non-linear narrative where things just happen for the sole purpose of exploring the discreet charm of the bourgeoisie which the title tells us it's about.  In other words it's a social critique of the upper classes.  The way they react and behave in the situations in the film is very funny.  I recommend this movie.

It's tough to review a movie you barely understood,so I'll just wing it as much as I can. I really didn't understand this movie all that much. I'm guessing it was about the life of the high-class folks of France and how strange it can be. I did,though,appreciate the weird scenes with Rafael shooting the other guy and Bloody Sargeant day.  This movie did have one scene that I thought was a little too dark,and that was the scene with the priest and the dying murderer. When you see it,you'll know. One scene ,however,I liked for no apparent reason and that was the 2nd time you see the group walking down the road when the dude stops to tie his shoe and when they start playing with the branches. I don't know if it was well filmed or what,but I loved it. Overall,not bad but not good-only because I couldn't understand it.

The Discreet Charm successfully champions an undermining of bourgeoisie lifestyle and the satirisation of ingrained, arbitrary class consciousness. If our minds are tuned to the high-brow concentration required that isâ¦

Well that's 100 minutes of my life I'll never get back! Turgid, surrealist fare & found it impossible to sympathise with any of the characters. Beautifully played, they may have been, but - for me - this was a scandalous waste of time. The adulatory reviews confound me - avoid at all costs.
Bizarre but not boring.

Silly, poignant and funny, but incisive nonetheless, the film lampoons the immorality of polite society and the evils it disguises.  Simultaneously it draws the viewer into the visions of the unreliable narrator, leaving an impression of confusion between truth and fiction which leads one to question which is ultimately more real.  Imagine Pan's Labyrinth meets Death at a Funeral.  On acid.
brave and irreverent in its attitude regarding sense, a unique kind of comedy not seen often
Everything you would expect from a surreal French comedy, hilarious, absurd, confusing and too long by quarter of an hour.
My Verdict : PRETENTIOUS CRAP....Whatever the so-called geeks fart about this....
Surrealist dreams the dream.
Cryptic, confusing but strangely compelling...
Absolutely classic! One of the best movies I've seen in my life.
A confusing, fascinating film that fails to connect emotionally but is a treat intellectually.

Only Bunuel could have made this film. Cinima's greatest surrealist. If someone were to say this was the greatest comedy ever made, I wouldn't argue. One of the 5 most inventive works of art in the history of film. Never again will a film surpass the brilliance of this.

Three fairly wealthy couples are trying to have dinner with each other, but for various reasons, there plans are often interrupted by an unforeseen event. One situation includes an Ambassador (Fernando Rey) who is being sought by terrorist who are attempting to kill him, only to confront his killer and let her get way. Another situation involves the three wives (Stephane Audren, Delphine Seyrig, Bulle Ogier) who sit down and try to have drink, only to be interrupted by a handsome, yet corrupt young soldier, who tells his utterly graphic story of being in the military. There are also sequences of affairs between the ambassador and the wives, as well as when they are arrested and another one where they are killed by set of terrorists. Portions of the film are reality while other portions are dreams. Who really knows what happened, but oh boy was this a riot to watch. Highly original, hilarious movie that moves at a breathtaking face with several wonderful, bizarre sequences that cannot be forgotten. Everyone, especially Rey, is excellent, along with the superb set pieces to add to the many great aspects of this crazy movie.
Take it like the conservative you are but only fantasize about in public.
A dream?  In a dream?  In a dream? And so on.
Frankly, Bunuel's "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie" hasn't charmed me entirely. I find "The Phantom of Liberty" more transparent and funny.
there were some very amusing scenes, and the dream sequences are very stylized, however after a while one begins to wonder what, if anything, is "le charme discret de la bourgeoisie" trying to say?

Very strange, but well done. I trusted the director amidst the untrustworthiness. I enjoyed it. I feel there's a lot I can dig out of it if I watched it again. 

Watched on March 31, 2012 on Netflix.
There's comedy to be found in the rituals and expectations of society, and director Luis Bunuel does not hold back.  It become too anecdotal at times, but it's still rather enjoyable.
Kinda fascinating at first, but then gets tedious.
I think I had this on our queue already, but I think my main impetus for finally watching it came from the mention in Metropolitan. Spoilers: If they get to eat, it's not happening. I think.
The greatest intellectual farce. All the scenes in the movie are interesting, bizarre, hilarious, and/or fantastic.
Bunuel is like a ridiculously dry version of Monty Python.  When this film was made, it looked like the upper class was dying.  But now, we know it didn't; it's just different.

Bunuel's sly, sardonic and surrealistic attack on the capricious nature of humanity, in particular the hypocritical conventions of the bourgeoisie, is an unqualified masterpiece, and by an standard one of the greatest films ever made.
How much was real, how much was a dream, and does it really matter?

  What the schtick launches is the chance to see some of the most narcissistic people around.  And not one of the "friends" in the group are innocent of putting their own wants and desires above the rest.
  From cocaine deals, to absurd dreams, to a randy couple running out to the garden, DCotB  is a wonderful comedy that should be given a chance.

Alfred Hitchcock considered him the best director of all times, which is why he fits nicely in my study of Hitchcock films.How can a film be both absurdist and overtly realistic? A combination of zany wit and a teaspoon of class struggle make this movie one of my all time favorites. It really rips off of the screen, and makes sure to leave a lasting impression in the mind. The only downfall is that the English subtitled version does a shoddy job of translating the numerous bon mots in the script. Take heart though, fair viewers, the French is surprisingly simple, such that anyway with a smattering of knowledge should be able to follow all of the dialogue.
While I stick by my claim that Bunuel's masterpiece was "The Exterminating Angel" this film is a great example of his form. A surrealist comedy where you won't laugh except in spite of yourself.

            There's something that's always bothered me about Hollywood movies, yet it's something that I never knew bothered me until now. The thing that irritates, troubles, and challenges me is the fact that almost all Hollywood films - good or bad - must have a point; they must make sense. They have a narrative that's genuinely easy to follow, they usually tend to have characters that we like and can relate to. I don't mind this, but then again, it's like I said; it bothers me the slightest bit, and that's good enough for me.

 I bring this up at this moment because Luis Buñuel's "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie" does not make sense; and it almost doesn't have much of a point beyond existence. It's a peculiar film that is meant to confuse; but through trickery, not through muddled screen-writing. The filmmaker must enjoy seeing us scratch our heads with puzzled faces; and he must like it every time we do it. Buñuel is known for repeating himself in some of his movies, but only because people like this quality about the man.

         Now, "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie" is about a group of bourgeois acquaintances who make several attempts to sit down and enjoy a nice dinner. The first attempt fails because they arrive at a time when the meal had not been planned or prepared. The second attempt is also not a success because the manager of the building which they would eat in had just passed away, that very moment.

 Man, I could go on-and-on about how many times this grand dinner fails to ensue, but I won't spoil too much. "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie" is a dish best served cold. You shouldn't know too much or too little about it. Hell, the only thing I personally believe you need to know about it when going in is that it's about people who sit down, multiple times, to eat, but never actually get down to it. 

  Throughout the film, there are some fascinating talks and depictions of dreams. Within these dreams are ghosts and voices that taunt, but cannot be heard. I loved the scene in which a speaking solider tells the dinner guests of his dream, in which he walks a lonely city road, but cannot find anyone who he had wanted to see. There are many complications with these characters throughout the movie, although few of them are actually characterized as many would hope they would be.

 But this is not your average movie. In fact, no surrealist film should be. Buñuel is a master when it comes to recycling ideas and even premises, or styles, and making us interested all over again. His fans will love this film, and maybe, just maybe, so will newcomers. It's fascinating, and it's often times funny; and sometimes even startling. You know you're watching a one-of-a-kind film when the dinner guests find out they're on a stage, acting in front of an audience full of people, although the sequence later proves to be nothing more than a dream. 

   Look. There's not much else I can say for this movie. It is what it is; well-written, well-directed trickery. The surrealism works, although it's not as extreme as I expected it to be. The visuals are not what matters here; what matters here, is ultimately, what the film wants to do and how much of that it accomplishes. Some may argue that it's not perfect, but I have a good counter-attack for that one: how is it not? The film is interesting, perhaps even intellectual. It is confusing, but decidedly so. It could not have been made any other way, and I openly love it as it is. This is a perfect movie; one of director Buñuel's best. See it because it exists, and because it's as good as it is, and there's really no other reasons beyond those.
Bunuel's greatest film. also one of the funniest and weirdest films ever made. Surrealism and comedy perfectly combined.

I'm not too sure what to say after watching this movie, but I'm pretty sure it was amazing. This is the first full-length film I've seen from the legendary surrealist/satirist Luis Bunuel (having seen only his notorious short Un Chien Andalou), and it does make me want to see his other work. I guess the quickest way to describe this movie is that it feels like what would happen if David Lynch's movies became a lot more watchable and funny.

There is and isn't a plot to speak of. The movie focuses on six characters, a bunch of French upper-class nitwits (well, one of them is an ambassador), who keep trying to sit down to dinner together, but keep getting interrupted by increasingly bizarre circumstances. Some of these interruptions are really funny. There are also random interludes where some supporting character who has not been seen before and will not be seen again tells everyone about his creepy dream/memory. The movie is also continually playing with us in terms of its levels of reality - at one point, I think, we are seeing what the movie tells us is a dream, within what surprisingly turns out to be a dream, which itself turns out to be in another dream, which itself turns out to be in another (I think). It's like Inception, but without any logic or rules. You could subject the movie to intense analysis to try to sort all that out, but I think to do so would be to miss the point, as the movie is probably honestly just messing around.

The cast is excellent. The one actor I recognized was Fernando Rey, who had played the French drug dealer in The French Connection the year before this movie. He was really insufferable in a villainous way in The French Connection, and really insufferable in a hilarious way in this movie. The rest of the cast is extremely good at playing annoying, petty-bourgeois types. 

This movie won the Best Foreign Language Film Oscar for its year, and was also nominated for Best Original Screenplay, an impressive achievement for a film that a) is foreign and b) has no true plot. It did deserve those, though, I think. The movie just has this unique feel to it; I'm willing to bet there's nothing else like this except for other Bunuel films. You never find a movie that can at once be funny, creepy, satirical, and boldly in defiance of normal narrative structure all at once. While it's not funny in a laugh-out-loud sense for the most part, it is very funny in a bemused, wry-grin sort of way. I definitely have to explore more Bunuel movies now.

I have a certain love-hate relationship with surrealist films, with the likes of "Inland Empire" and Godard's "Week End" I consider to be too pretentious, while some like "El Topo" and "Eraserhead" I highly regard. But Luis Bunuel's "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie" is on a different level, having its share of self-indulgent moments, while maintaining the sharp wit and sarcasm of its satiric nature, all the while being a critic on excessive lifestyles without taking itself too seriously. People that belong to the  Bourgeois society, when portrayed in a darker light, can be the most irritating of film characters, but when took on stage to forcibly look at their own shortcomings that they hide with their material excesses, can be one of film lovers' secret pleasures to watch on celluloid: Let the self-obsessed hypocrites be deconstructed by some unknown force. But Bunuel, although making the film to be a major attack on the particular social class, did not finish the film laughing along with the audience; But more of like postponing the punchline of an insult joke. As shown in the film, when it's a dream, "kill them all!" and "humiliate the bastards!" can be some of the most recurring of proletariat battlecries, when fantasy fades and reality sets back, "absolve them of their sins" more like. Maybe having them miss some of their lavish lamb chops and caviars is enough. Surrealist film at its top form.

More likely: "The exquisite art of the dinner party". Buñuel crafts another heretic masterpiece that's part spoof, part social critique with a pinch of sex, violence and all things nice. Simply beautiful.

Luis Bunuel's "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie" hardly resembles what you'd call a typical movie. It's structure is anecdotal, and it therefore comes off as a series of surrealist short films. These sequences could stand on their own - they're simple stories involving the obscure lusts and temptations lingering underneath the facade of manners. To Bunuel, the idea of a bourgeoisie lifestyle is contradictory to our animal instincts, and he has no problem making fun of some of the absurdities we carry out in an effort to remain "civilized". 

The plot is quite simple: six bourgeois friends are trying to sit down and have a meal together. Each time, however, their efforts are thwarted. The wide array of obstacles include arriving to the host's house on the wrong day, finding out that a restaurant owner is being mourned in an adjacent room, and, eventually, finding out that their stale roast chicken is actually a stage prop. Things seem to get stranger as they progress, with some of the scenes in the last half hour being dreams within dreams. For instance, we hear of the horror story of a prison guard who comes back to kill. Then, of course see him: ethereal, bloody, and blue. And, at another point, a soldier recalls his childhood, which also involves the supernatural.

I've only seen a few of Bunuel's films, but what i've found striking is how they're able to be critical without being angry or vengeful. The films i've seen all point fingers at the same social class of people, but each time Bunuel seems to identify with them rather than hate them. He realizes the absurdities, the inconsistencies, the hypocrisy, and the illusions, and he, in a way, embraces them. When, for instance, a group of soldiers fire on the dinner guests in a dream sequence, one of them takes refuge under a table. He then foolishly gives away his position by trying to sneak some food off of his plate - he can't help himself. While his ideas can be cynical, he's presenting them in such a manner that it's amusing and far from hateful. The films, no matter how dark, are comic and completely charming.

Like "Belle de Jour" and "Diary of a Chambermaid", the film deals with sexual desires and fantasies hidden behind the illusion of grounded stability. There is a bishop who acts out his fantasies of working as a gardener for the wealthy, and we also see two hosts head outside to make love while they're expecting guests. When they arrive back in the house, dirty and picking leaves off of each other, it's the perfect contrast between "civilized" humans and ones driven by animalistic instinct.

"The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie" is certainly an odd film that, at times, will leave you scratching your head. But it's such a welcome departure from more conventional films that strictly follow their structure. It's loose and playful, and thus it establishes a memorable dreamlike quality. I can't say I made sense of it all, but I don't know if that's the point. What matters most, however, is how humorous, charming, and inventive it is.

Combine the surrealism of David Lynch with the absurdism of Monty Python, and you get an approximation of this movie.  There isn't really a plot here, but some things happen, which I will describe to the best of my ability.  The ambassador from the country of Miranda attempts to enjoy a dinner with friends, but there always seems to be some interruption to keep them from enjoying their meal.  The ambassador also happens to be a drug smuggler, and is in constant threat of assassination by guerillas from Miranda.  Meanwhile, the Bishop comes round to the friends' house and announces he'd like to be their gardener.  A soldier stops the women in a little cafe (where they've run out of everything but water), to tell the story of how he murdered his stepfather, and then walks away.  The last third of the movie seems to be a series of dream sequences, where each of the party guests dreams of murders and arrests.  Apart from a few vignettes, the movie isn't very interesting (and I really hate to oversell the surrealism, which doesn't show up really until the last third of the movie), and neither are the performances.  It's only memorable in that it will someday vex you to try and remember the title of "that one weird french movie".

This is basically a movie about how a group of people try to sit down to have dinner but that never happens. Pretty much every thing imagineable besides that happens. This is Luis Bunuel's masterpiece and remember he mad Belle De Jour. I just love movies like this where anything could happen at any time. There are many dream like scenes and most scenes you won't even know whether they are real or not until the next scene. This is not a complete comedy though. The story that the soldier tells is haunting in its own way. I really don't want to give anything away here but please put on this movie with an open mind and with no expectations whatsoever. Your mind will certainly be put to the test. The thing about this movie is that there really is no beginning or end but just a series of bizar and extremely well written, highly quotable scenes with vibrant dialogue and crazy characters. That's really the best I can explain this film.

Let's be honest right away: if you are the type of person that would track this down solely because it won the Best Foreign Film Oscar in 1972, chances are good you will hate this.  If you love absurd situations with no continuity or logic, chances are good you will love this and are a Bunuel fan.  If you are still reading and do not fit into either category, the rest of this review is for you since both previously mentioned parties will have made up their minds.  A group of six aristocratic snobs cannot eat dinner.  That's it.  One time they sit down at the table and a passing army barges in.  Another time at a restaurant, they discover a funeral is taking place for the manager of the establishment.  Later on at another meal, they are all arrested.  Oh, and tales of a boy's mother's ghost telling him to poison his supposed father, piano torture (it makes sense if you see it), theatre performances and more round out the flick.  And none of it quite gels as female terrorists, dream sequences without warning and a gardening priest make their presences felt.  In anyone else's hands, this would have been disastrous but Bunuel shines as he mocks upper society, religion, the army and other ripe targets.  No one is safe, including the audience who is never fully aware of what is going on, and the result is an experience you will either love or try to immediately forget about (probably over dinner).

i don't want this film to mean anything. i just want to watch it freely. I don't even want to offer a critique. To try and find symbolism in this surreal piece of art would be so crude. All I know is that this film gives me something real, even if it's only a seedling for a bizarre dream.

This movie is about people who perpetually show up for dinner and occasionally even sit down for it, but are never able to eat. They arrive on the wrong night, or are dismayed to find the dead body of the restaurant owner in the next room, or are bothered by military maneuvers. Dinner is the cardinal civil convention of the middle classes, a means of showing affluence and social grace. It also affords the aid of something to do and something to chat about, and that is a blessed comfort, not only because so many of the bourgeoisie have nothing much to talk about, and there is a vast lot of things they wish will not be brought up.

Most movies make believe their plots are de facto and that we need to buy into them unequivocally. Comedies are sanctioned to be remiss in this case. Most of the films of Luis Bunuel, who made nearly 40, are comedies somehow, but he doesn't go for shticks and wisecracks, although it seems that way from a distance. His ironic sense of humor is more like a jeer, witty and caustic.

The humor in this absurdist film is in the way Bunuel barges in on the meals with the back-door goings-on that skulk below the facade of his deteriorating European nobility: irrationality, extramarital affairs, drug dealing, swindling, military coups, debauchery and the inertia of apathy. His main characters are politicians, the military and the wealthy, but in a giving state of mind he lays on a supporting character to ridicule the church, a bishop whose fetish is to disguise as a gardener and work as a servant in the gardens of the rich. This Oscar-winning head trip was Bunuel's most successful film. It was released in a year when civil anxiety was at its apex, the Vietnam War was in imbued blossom, and the upper middle class was a stylish aim of contempt. How contrastive to see it in 2009, when wealth is by and large longed for and coveted. The essential crowd for the film in 1972 viewed it as holding others up to censure; the essential crowd today will, if it is "discreet," view it as holding itself up to censure.

From the start, we are conscious of the way the characters behave themselves. They emanate their prestige, certain of who they are, and exhibit their class in society like a uniform. Seemingly austere Fernando Rey's tiny grandstander of an ambassador, suave and rather penetrating Stephane Audran's affluent lady of the house, Bulle Ogier's disinterested and alcoholic sister, all behave like they're performing a play. And highlight the bishop, played with an oddly passionate superficiality by Julien Bertheau, who shows up at the door in gardener's clothes and is disdainfully kicked out, just to return in his holy attire to "explain himself," and be welcomed.

The misanthropic daydream is fractured into independent scenes, showing the dull face of the fashionable privileged and the appetites that crouch underneath it. A couple awaits guests for dinner. In the bedroom, they are bowled over by horniness. The guests show up. Now they cannot have sex in the bedroom because the wife "makes too much noise," the husband carps, so they sneak out a window and vigorously screw in the woods. Then they creep back into the house, leaves and grass in their hair. Bourgeoisie civilities, Bunuel quaintly suggests, are the meagerest disguise for our primal capacities. Another instance: After soldiers blitz the dinner guests, a man evades doom by hiding under a table, yet gives himself away by gluttonously reaching up for the uneaten meat on his plate.

The film's story progression is blithely ruptured by Bunuel's methods. As women have drinks in a garden cafÃ©, a lieutenant walks over and begins a distressing account of his childhood. We see his autobiography in flashback. He wishes them good day and leaves. A dinner party progresses abnormally when the roast chickens are dropped by the servant and emerge as stage props, and then the curtain goes up and the guests discover themselves on stage facing an audience. Dreams entwine inside dreams, not due to the characters being baffled, but because Bunuel is entertaining himself by using such barefaced gimmicks.

This sardonic musing, co-written with Jean-Claude Carriere with quick wit and intellectual enthusiasm, is not grim or agitated, but mocking and amazed. Financed by the French producer Serge Silberman, Bunuel was finally at deserved liberty to satiate his far-ranging imagination, and the movie is free of any commercial or coherent conditions. Bunuel was contemptuous, though not disheartened. We say one thing and do another, yes, but that doesn't make us immoral, just human and, from his outlook, hilarious. He has been dubbed a depraved filmmaker, but the more I discover his films the more insight and affirmation I see, as well as a strong social awareness.
